Award.AwardTitle: BCSP: The Emergence of Inactivity: Adaptive Task Allocation in Complex Distributed Systems, or Why Are There so Many Lazy Ants?
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most important, perhaps the biggest unanswered question in biology is how a collection of relatively simple parts can form structures that are organized, effective and often beautiful. This occurs in the origin of life, where clusters of molecules form cells; in development, where initially unspecialized cells form an embryo; and in many other systems, including insect colonies, where an aggregation of small insects generates adaptive group behavior. The same phenomenon also affects humans more directly, where computer clusters, power grids, and people in organizations display unforeseen group-level behavior. This project specifically investigates the behavioral rules that individual units in such groups may use to divide up tasks. Division of labor plays an important role in many collective systems and a systematic understanding of how best to achieve it is lacking. This project will make substantive contributions to the fields of Animal Behavior, Computer Science and Engineering. Ants will be used as an empirical study system and mathematical models will be developed to generalize findings to a variety of questions, particularly in engineering. Results from this project will be used as a stepping-stone to applied software development. An interdisciplinary teaching program will be developed to train a new generation of biologists and engineers who can make use of insights from both of these fields. Short film documentaries and other teaching tools will engage the general public.

This project aims to provide both detailed empirical data on how social insect colonies generate an efficient and robust division of labor and a broader theoretical framework that will deliver insights on optimized, self-organized task allocation that applies widely across complex systems. Individually marked ants and a semi-automated tracking system will facilitate comprehensive data collection. For example, do fluctuations in the need for work drive changing activity levels? This will show whether the many apparently inactive ants found in colonies are necessary reserves and how flexible task allocation strategies are. The effect of task allocation on insect colony fitness will be directly measured. The development models will be used to predict how inactivity may result from particular strategies and how alternative strategies perform in terms of accuracy, flexibility, robustness and specialization. In distributed computing theory, this work will push the envelope by providing more powerful models that take into account a combination of discrete, continuous, dynamic and probabilistic behavior. The investigators will also hold an annual workshop on Biological Distributed Algorithms, bringing together top researchers in biology, computing and robotics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What is the best way to assign tasks to workers in a group? This very general question about task allocation is relevant for many biological and engineered systems. Intuitively and, as this project has shown, mathematically, it is particularly difficult to solve when the need for work in different tasks changes dynamically, and when the workers have limited information and differ in their capacity to perform different types of tasks. This project used social insects, such as ants and bees, as an example system that is evolutionarily optimized to discover both how the problem of task allocation can be solved, and to study what the benefits of different strategies may be. Some of the main results:

(1) A buffer force: Insect colonies often contain many 'workers' not apparently working. This project demonstrated that many of these are likely young, not-yet-competent workers staying out of the way; but some are a reserve force that becomes active when task demands increase.

(2) Different strategies: The project showed that contrary to some current literature, individual insect workers may use not only information from a variety of sources to decide which task to do next, but also use different decision rules depending on which task is involved. In particular, some types of work may be performed by much more specialized individuals, and may be selected more based on intrinsic factors, while other tasks may be selected more based on external information. The project also demonstrated that the ‘task stimulus response threshold mechanism’, previously proposed to be ubiquitous in social insects, is unlikely to be responsible for division of labor, empirically in at least the ant species studied here, and generally on theoretical grounds.

(3) Quantity and quality: At the system or group level, social insects and other systems can also decide whether to use their resource budget on many low-quality (e.g. in insects, small) or few high-quality (e.g. large) workers. Empirical and theory work in this project shows that some insects opt for a mix of cheap, low-quality workers and expensive high-quality workers, and that this is the optimal strategy when the payoff of higher quality workers differs between types of work. In this extension of the comparative advantage principle, colonies with mixed-quality workers benefit from division of labor even if low-quality workers underperform high-quality ones in all tasks.

(4) Student research: College students as well as graduate (MSc and PhD) students were trained as part of this project, with an emphasis on achieving rigorous, objective scientific results using strong inference (the ‘scientific method) as well as career skills such as data analysis (coding and statistics), presentation (writing and speaking) and professionalism (independence, responsibility, communication). The project supported such training through the opportunity of engaging in original scientific research, being part of a team of researchers with a mix of seniority levels, and professional conference presentations. The project in particular offered opportunities in interdisciplinary training, enabling students both in biology and computer science to learn about the goals and procedures of the other field, and empowering them to initiate future collaborations between these fields. One avenue for this was the annual Biological Distributed Algorithms workshop (BDA), coorganized by both PIs on this project.

(5) K-12 student hands-on projects: The project also enabled the establishment of ‘The Cricket Project’, an outreach program in which a university scientist partnered with local Elementary school teachers, providing materials, mentoring, and in-person support to allow them to implement hands-on insect behavior experiments in Tucson public school classrooms. Kids, primarily in grades K-4, used the same method of strong inference to test hypotheses about cricket personality, cockroach communication, etc. and learned about the process of science.
